title: Computing Authoring Tests from Competency Questions: Experimental Validation

author: Matt Dennis, School of Computing, University of Portsmouth

segmentation: My name is Matt Dennis.
I'm based in the University of Portsmouth and this paper is about computing authoring test from competency questions and the validation of how we do that.
This is in partnership with my colleagues at the University of Redeem Keys Vantiv to Daniela, who died there.

Bit of basic information about competency questions constructing ontologies is difficult for beginners to do because they're quite difficult concepts to start with.

So users and developers frequently fail to comprehend important implication of the information contained in ontology and also the implications that happen when ontologies are changed.
So when you axioms are added or subtracted, this can have knock on effects.
The rest of the ontology.
These challenges have led to the notion of competency questions, which is simply a question that are finished.
Ontology should be able to answer, for example, a competency question for.
A restaurant main My ask, something like what is the price of asparagus soup and once the ontology, the reason is able to answer that question, the ontology can be considered to be complete.

Recently, a number of authors have proposed that these competency questions because they're useful and they give a measure of when and ontologies complete that they should be integrated in part into part of the authoring interfaces for creating ontologies.

One approach which has been used before by researchers in our research group, particularly tile proposed the competency equation, that competency, question driven, ontology authoring approach, which proposes an authoring interface which can checks continually during authoring which of those CQS are able to be answered by an ontology.

When they're being created.

What does it mean for a competency question to be handled correctly well?
Our research project draws on a key concept in linguistics, which is a presupposition.

So, for example, if you say, what is the price of cutlery in when asked in a restaurant, you you presuppose that cutlery is for sale in the restaurant, and if it's not, the question can't be answered.
Similarly, if you ask in a coffee shop which of the drinks or coffee drinks you assume that coffee is for sale in the shop, but it also sells things which are not coffee.
So.
We can move to measure these, whether it comes into question is able to be answered by Nan, told on top by an ontology, by deriving authoring tests from the conversation questions themselves.
So if we ask ourselves the question which pizzas contain chocolate, the positive presupposition is that a pizza can contain chocolate.
And then there's also the compliment presupposition that a pizza cannot contain chocolate, and that's also satisfiable in your ontology.

In previous work runner style map, the types of constancy question authors tend to ask and defined different archetypes for them, and then they detail how these authoring tests can be derived for each of these different types of archetypes of competency questions.

To do this, the robots designers give the robot.

So for experiment we made a very simple hot drinks ontology.

Which we tell it that all drinks or coffee drinks or tea drinks.
We say that coffee beans contain caffeine and etc etc so you can see it's just a very simple ontology based in a coffee shop for the use in the experiment.

And the English study was with 54 participants, 54% of them were male.
We recruited them through crowdsourcing on Mechanical Turk.
So these were a lay audience of just random workers on Mechanical Turk.
They were based in the United States.

And they also had to pass an English test for English fluency to make sure that they understood enough to be able to take part in the study.
Then the DL version was run with 15 participants through a reasoning web summer school in Aberdeen and this had beginner and intermediate DL practitioners.

40% of them were intermediate.

A beginner and intermediate DL practitioners.

It must be, and there's one there which says it must be possible for a coffee drink to not contain tea leaves.
